newsitem.title: USA: US OPTIONS FOCUS/Uncertainty high in Staples/Depot.
newsitem.headline: US OPTIONS FOCUS/Uncertainty high in Staples/Depot.

text.p: Investors expect the proposed merger between office superstores Office Depot Inc and Staples Inc to be completed but options activity suggests uncertainy over the timing remains high, traders said Wednesday.

"Today the option activity suggests the deal may be consummated but the timing of it is a little uncertain," Frank McGarvey of TFM Investment Group said, referring to Staples options, which trade on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.
"The key word right now is uncertainty," he said.
Staples, which had some of the most active options around, was down 13/16 at 21-7/16 in late trade Wednesday.
Office Depot, whose options on the American Stock Exchange were fairly busy, added 3/8 to 19-1/8.
Michael Schwartz, managing director at Oppenheimer & Co, said some of the Staples option activity appeared to be from arbitrageurs protecting positions and taking on synthetic stock positions.
"It looks to me like some arbitrageurs were buying the March 30 in-the-money puts to protect their positions and taking June 20 calls for stock substitution," he said.
"If they have to keep rolling out the puts for protection, they will," he added.
McGarvey said both strategies were taking place.

"Some people were closing out positions they had and some were opening positions and buying Office Depot against it," he said. "Net net, some people were closing and others were trying to re-establish positions."
He said the call activity reflected investors' uncertainty.
The Staples March 20 call traded more than 9,700 contracts, making it the most active individual equity option.
The Staples March 17-1/2 call traded nearly 7,000 contracts.
Other busy Staples options included the March 30 put, which traded 1,675 contracts, the March 22-1/2 put, which traded 1,060 contracts, and the June 20 call, which traded more than 1,000.
Among Office Depot options, the most active was the April 15 put, with volume of 2,125 contracts.
The March 20 call traded nearly 2,100, the April 22-1/2 call traded 1,505 and the April 20 call traded about 1,045.
On Monday, consumer advocate Ralph Nader released a study that found lower prices where Staples and Office Depot stores compete with each other and called on the government to prevent the merger.
McGarvey at TFM Investment Group said the Nader comments raised speculation yesterday that the deal would fall through.

The two companies have already extended the Hart-Scott-Rodino waiting period to March 5 from February 25 and said Wednesday they intended to delay special shareholder meetings for a merger vote to March 7 from February 27. ((--G.Crawford, 312 408 8750/Email: derivatives@reuters.com))
